docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN the Regional Plan Association published a study in 1983 arguing that the way to reverse the deterioration of downtown Brooklyn was to turn it into the city's third central business district, after downtown and midtown Manhattan, the outcome was anything but certain. The uncertainties continued over the years even as the cluster of buildings known as Metrotech Center rose and filled with offices; one developer, after years of frustration, pulled down a billboard promising a hotel's imminent arrival. Now the steelwork for that hotel, the first new one in Broolyn in 50 years, is rising next to Metrotech, which has become a $1-billion, five-million-square-foot development of new and renovated buildings around a landscaped commons. The latest building, known as Renaissance Plaza, will house a Marriott hotel with 384 guest rooms and large meeting spaces, as well as a 32-story office tower with a total of 1.4 million square feet of office space.
docs.abstract: Metrotech, proposed by Regional Plan Assn in 1983 to reverse deterioration of downtown Brooklyn, has become $1-billion development of new and renovated buildings around landscaped commons; photos; map; latest is Renaissance Plaza, first new hotel to be built in Brooklyn in fifty years; Polytechnic University, one of five colleges in area, is in midst of $150-million fund-raising campaign to complete its campus; urban planner Mitchell Moss recalls that Polytechnic president, George Bugliarello, envisioned research and development site like Silicon Valley; developers recall putting together parcels (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: Attorney General Dennis C. Vacco of New York said on Friday night that he would urge legislative leaders to dedicate half the money the state would receive under the legal settlement with the tobacco industry to establish a program providing medical coverage to hundreds of thousands of uninsured children each year. Mr. Vacco estimated that the state would receive $400 million this year as a result of the settlement of its lawsuit against tobacco companies. That figure will grow in subsequent years as it is adjusted for inflation, increasing to as much as $700 million four years from now, he said.

headline.main: New York May Use Money to Aid Children

docs.lead_paragraph: CONSIDER the advantages of this scenario: a visit to your primary-care doctor indicated that the medication you had been using to control hypertension is no longer working. The doctor considers all the factors and looks to other pharmaceuticals to control the condition. In the course of discussing your symptoms, you tell the doctor that a recent depression over job loss led you to a psychiatrist who prescribed an antidepressant treatment that made you feel well again but apparently had a direct impact on your blood pressure.
docs.abstract: Comment on some new software that can helps doctors provide better patient care at lower cost (M)

docs.section_name: Technology; Health; New York and Region

docs.lead_paragraph: As they put the finishing touches on a new election-year budget, state lawmakers and Governor Whitman found themselves in a political quandary: there was too much money to spend. Gone are the dire warnings made only a few months ago that hundreds of state workers would lose their jobs. The bull market on Wall Street and the state's strong economy have poured at least $590 million in unanticipated tax revenues into the state's coffers. And the Legislature's approval earlier this month of Governor Whitman's $2.75 billion pension borrowing plan clears the way for the state to skip $590 million in scheduled pension payments this year.

headline.main: Making Do in a Year When Money Abounds

docs.abstract: Comment on Gov Christine Whitman's spending plans in year in which New Jersey's budget is flush with money (S)
